case_name: Sub Divisional Officer, Sirsa & Naib Tehsildar-cum-Managing Officer, Sirsa v. Gurbachan Singh

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 187 of 1959 was filed by special leave from Punjab High Court judgment dated August 18, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 187 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 18, 1958, of the Punjab, High Court in- Criminal Original No. 20 of 1958.

facts.text: First appellant was Sub Divisional Officer, Sirsa, District Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants before us bear the same name. One of them was the Sub Divisional Officer, Sirsa, District Hisear and the other Naib Tehsildarcum-Managing Officer, Sirsa, same district at the relevant time.

facts.text: Second appellant was Naib Tehsildar-cum-Managing Officer, Sirsa, District Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants before us bear the same name. One of them was the Sub Divisional Officer, Sirsa, District Hisear and the other Naib Tehsildarcum-Managing Officer, Sirsa, same district at the relevant time.

facts.text: Budh Singh, a displaced person, was allotted land in village Jagmalera, Tehsil Sirsa, District Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: The facts alleged against the appellants were these. One Budh Singh, a displaced person, was allotted some land in village Jagmalera, Tehsil Sirsa, District Hissar.

facts.text: Land allotted to Budh Singh was forcibly occupied by respondent Gurbachan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The land allotted to Budh Singh was, it was stated by the appellants, forcibly occupied by the respondent Gurbachan Singh.

facts.text: On May 9, 1958, appellant No. 1 made an order that Budh Singh and other allottees would be given possession on May 20, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On May 9. 1958 appellant No. 1 made an order that Budh Singh and other allottees like him would be given possession of the land, allotted to them. The date fixed for such delivery of possession was May 20, 1958.

facts.text: On May 16, 1958, Gurbachan Singh and others filed petitions under Art. 226 challenging the action.

anchor.surface_text: On May 16, 1958 Gurbachan Singh and a number of other persons who were similarly threatened with dispossession filed petitions to the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the action threatened against them.

facts.text: On May 16, 1958, Chief Justice issued stay order till May 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were put up before the learned Chief Justice on that very day, namely, May 16, 1958, when he issued an order staying delivery of possession till May 19, 1958, when the petitions were to companye up for admission before a Division Bench,

facts.text: On May 19, 1958, Division Bench extended stay till May 23, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On May 19, 1958, the Division Bench extended the operation of the stay order until May 23, 1958.

facts.text: First stay order communicated to appellants on May 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the appellants did number dispute that the first order staying delivery of possession up to May 19, 1958 was companymunicated to them on May 19, 1958 on which date the numberice from the High Court reached Sirsa.

facts.text: Second stay order not officially communicated to appellants till May 21, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a numberice of the second order extending the stay of delivery possession till May 23, 1958, was number officially companymunicated to the appellants till May 21, 1958.

facts.text: On May 20, 1958, appellants dispossessed Gurbachan Singh and handed possession to Budh Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation on behalf of the respondent was that on May 20, 1958, which was the relevant date, the two appellants were informed by certain interested persons... In spite of this information, however, the second appellant... formally dispossessed the respondent and handed over possession of the land to Budh Singh.

facts.text: Respondent filed contempt application on May 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent made an application, to the High  companyrt, for taking suitable action against the two appellants. This application was made, oil May 27, 1958.

facts.text: Punjab High Court (Falshaw J) found appellants guilty of contempt but administered warning and Rs. 50 costs each.

anchor.surface_text: On this application the High Court issued numberice and after hearing the parties, Falshaw, J.  as he then was  who dealt with the application came to the companyclusion that the two appellants were aware of the order... He held them guilty of companytempt of companyrt, but... merely administered a warning to them and directed them to pay the companyts of the respondent.

facts.text: Appellants informed by Bir Singh and Avtar Singh at 6:30 a.m. on May 20, 1958 that stay extended.

anchor.surface_text: In para. 17 of the application... it was stated that at 6-30 a.m. on May 20, 1958, two persons named Bir Singh and Avtar Singh went personally to the house of appellant No. 2 and told him that the stay order had been extended by the High Court...

facts.text: Written application presented to appellant No. 2 at 7:40 a.m. on May 20, 1958 stating stay till May 23.

anchor.surface_text: In paras. 18, 19 and 20... at about 7-40 a.m. on May 20, 1958 a written application was filed before appellant No. 2 in which it was stated that the High Court had stayed delivery of possession till May 23, 1958 this application was drafted by an advo- cate named Ganga Bishan...

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 admitted receiving application and affidavit from Didar Singh on May 20, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appellant No. 2, however, in his companynter-affidavit admitted that on May 20, 1958 an application was presented to him by Didar Singh at about 7-40 a.m. He further admitted that an affidavit in support of the application was also presented to him.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 told Didar Singh he could not act without seeing the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of these documents I told Shri Didar Singh that I companyld number act on the application and suspend the proceedings for dispossession unless I was shown the order of stay alleged to have been made by the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court majority held appellants knew of stay extension in all cases including respondent's.

anchor.surface_text: ...the only reasonable inference is that though the application and the affidavit were made on behalf of Didar Singh, both the appellants were informed that the High Court had granted an extension of the stay order in all 4 he cases.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, upheld High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Dayal J dissented, held no contempt committed.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-I have bad the privilege of perusing the, Judgment of my learned brother S. K. Das, J., but regret My inability to hold that the appellants companymitted companytempt of Court.

facts.text: No actual dispossession occurred due to standing cotton crop and crowd.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in para. 22... though appellant No. 2 made a report about delivery of possession... numberactual dispossession companyld be made because companyton crop was standing on the land and a large number of persons had gathered there.

facts.text: Appellant No. 2 reported delivery of possession to Budh Singh.

anchor.surface_text: As to the first submission wemay draw attention to the statements of appellant No. 2 in para. 21 of his affidavit in which he said that so far as the respondents land was companycerned, possession was delivered to Budh Singh.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 18, 1958, of the Punjab, High Court in- Criminal Original No. 20 of 1958. Gopal Singh and P. D. Menon, for the appellants.

issues.text: Whether the appellants had knowledge of the High Court's order extending the stay of delivery of possession till May 23, 1958, specifically in the respondent Gurbachan Singh's case, sufficient for willful disobedience constituting contempt.

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, it has been contended that on the materials on the record, the High Court was wrong in proceeding on the footing that the two appellants were informed by the interested parties that an extension of the stay order up to May 23, 1958, had been granted in the case of the respondent.

issues.text: Whether official communication or formal service of a prohibitory stay order is required for holding the appellants guilty of contempt, or is knowledge aliunde sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: The second point which has been urged on behalf of the appellants is that in the absence of an official communication of the order, they were justified in not acting on what they came to know from interested parties and their advocate.

issues.text: Whether there was actual delivery of possession to Budh Singh in disobedience of the stay order, or was the action trifling such that no contempt lies.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly our attention has been drawn to the statements made by the respondent in para. 22 of his petition to the effect that though appellant No. 2 made a report about delivery of possession in respect of the land of the respondent, no actual dispossession could be made because cotton crop was standing on the land.

issues.text: Whether the appellants could justify their actions while also offering apology in contempt proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second submission, it is enough to point out that in a matter relating to contempt of court, there cannot be both justification and apology, See M. Shareef v. The Honble Judges of the High Court of Nagpur.

issues.text: Whether the respondent's petition contained precise allegations of specific acts of contempt in quasi-criminal proceedings, and whether he approached with clean hands.

anchor.surface_text: Contempt proceedings are criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings. It is essential that the accusation made against the opposite party by the petitioner for taking action against him should be precise and should clearly make out... it is clear that the respondent did not come to Court with clean hands.

issues.text: Whether proof of notice of the prohibitory order must be beyond reasonable doubt in contempt proceedings affecting liberty.

anchor.surface_text: bearing in mind that the liberty of the subject is to-be affected, I think that those who assert that there was such a notice ought to prove it beyond reasonable doubt.

arguments.court_reasoning: Multiple affidavits consistent; advocate involved; no specific denial.

arguments.claim: Ganga Bishan not duly appointed counsel; statements lack weight.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of the statements and the affidavits, I am not prepared to hold that Ganga Bishan was the duly appointed counsel for Didar Singh.

arguments.claim: Precedents like Oswald, Bryant, Langley require reliable notice, not mere interested parties; telegram from non-officer insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: This case is not authority for the proposition that information conveyed... by telegram from a person who is not an officer of the Court would amount to the requisite notice...

arguments.court_reasoning: Oswald supports aliunde notice for prohibitory; advocate is officer of court.

holdings.text: the appellants knew of the order of the High Court in all the cases and it is not correct to say that the appellants knew of the order of the High Court only in one case and not in the others.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we have come to the conclusion that the appellants knew of the order of the High Court in all the cases and it is not correct to say that the appellants knew of the order of the High Court only in one case and not in the others.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits from Ganga Bishan, Didar Singh, Teja Singh, Avtar Singh consistently state extension informed for all Jagmalera cases; appellants admitted receiving documents, no specific counter-affidavit denying knowledge in respondent's case; argument not raised in High Court.

holdings.text: in the matter of a prohibitory order it is well-settled that it is not necessary that the order should have been served upon the party against whom it has been granted in order to justify committal for breach of such an order, provided it is proved that the person complained against had notice of the order aliunde.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that those decisions are in point, because we are dealing with a prohibitory order and in the matter of a prohibitory order it is well-settled that it is not necessary that the order should have been served upon the party against whom it has been granted in order to justify committal for breach of such an order, provided it is proved that the person complained against had notice of the order aliunde.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Oswald's rule on prohibitory orders; distinguishes mandatory orders requiring service; notice aliunde via advocate sufficient as appellants officers duty-bound to obey known valid High Court order.

holdings.text: we are satisfied that there was in this case in the eye of the law, a willful disobedience of the order of the High Court staying delivery of possession, even though the appellants might have wrongly but honestly believed that it was not safe to act on the information given to them by Ganga Bishan.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into considerations all these, circumstances we are satisfied that there was in this case in the eye of the law, a willful disobedience of the order of the High Court staying delivery of possession, even though the appellants might have wrongly but honestly believed that it was not safe to act on the information given to them by Ganga Bishan.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Knowledge proven aliunde via advocate's application and affidavit; background enmity no justification to doubt authenticity; did not proceed in Didar Singh's case showing selective action.

holdings.text: the two appellants took the very action which was prohibited by the High Court by its order dated May 19, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This statement of appellant No. 2 clearly shows that the two appellants took the very action which was prohibited by the High Court by its order dated May 19, 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant No. 2's affidavit admits possession delivered to Budh Singh despite respondent's claim of no actual dispossession due to crop/crowd; formal action taken prohibited by stay.

holdings.text: in a matter relating to contempt of court, there cannot be both justification and apology.

anchor.surface_text: As to the second submission, it is enough to point out that in a matter relating to contempt of court, there cannot be both justification and apology, See M. Shareef v. The Honble Judges of the High Court of Nagpur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from M. Shareef v. Hon'ble Judges of Nagpur High Court holds inconsistent defenses impermissible in contempt.

holdings.text: there are no grounds for interference with the order of the High Court. The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there are no grounds for interference with the order of the High Court. The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld High Court's finding of guilt with mild punishment considering honest belief; no error in proceedings.

holdings.text: the appellants committed no contempt of Court.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-I have had the privilege of perusing the, Judgment of my learned brother S. K. Das, J., but regret My inability to hold that the appellants committed contempt of Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: No willful disobedience as honest belief no order existed without official communication; respondent's petition imprecise, unclean hands; proof inadequate.

holdings.text: those who assert that there was such a notice ought to prove it beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: And, in a matter of this kind, bearing in mind that the liberty of the subject is to-be affected, I think that those who assert that there was such a notice ought to prove it beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent obiter: In contempt affecting liberty, notice aliunde must be proved beyond reasonable doubt; telegram from non-court officer insufficient per precedents like Langley.

holdings.text: Contempt proceedings are criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings. It is essential that the accusation made against the opposite party by the petitioner for taking action against him should be precise and should clearly make out

anchor.surface_text: Contempt proceedings are criminal or quasi-criminal proceedings. It is essential that the accusation made against the opposite party by the petitioner for taking action against him should be precise and should clearly make out

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent obiter: Petitioner must allege specific acts; respondent's petition lacked precise claim of dispossession, unclean hands.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between prohibitory orders and orders of an affirmative nature was adverted to in N. Baksi v. O. K. Ghosh 6 and a large number of decisions were referred to in support of the rule that in respect of a prohibitory order, service of the order was not essential for founding an action in contempt.

anchor.surface_text: In In re Bryant 1 the parties concerned wet, , informed by the solicitor of the judgment-debtor that the debtor had filed a liquidation petition in the London Bankruptcy Court and that application would be made at the next sitting of the Court to restrain further proceedings under the execution.

precedents.cited_proposition: parties informed by solicitor's telegram of injunction held to have disobeyed and committed contempt

precedents.citation: Ex parte Langley, Ex parte Smith, In re Bishop 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ex parte Langley, Ex parte Smith, In re Bishop 1 the facts were as follows. Bishop filed a liquidation petition in the London Bankruptcy Court on August 6, 1879. The same day the Court passed an order restraining until the 8th of September, further proceedings

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that those decisions are in point, because we are dealing with a prohibitory order and in the matter of a prohibitory order it is well-settled that it is not necessary that the order should have been served upon the party against whom it has been granted in order to justify committal for breach of such an order, provided it is proved that the person complained against had notice of the order aliunde.
